text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with another installment of cooking
with grass-fed beef this time we have
some beautiful beef bones from steve
normanton and we're going to make some
beef stock from scratch very easy to
make it home so when you buy grass-fed
beef you're also going to have access to
be phones so what we're going to do is
we're going to thaw five pounds we're
going to put those on a sheet pan you
can see I have a nice assortment here I
got some joints I got some center cut
bones you can see the marrow in there
that's what's going to make the stock so
rich we're also going to need some
mirepoix which is your classic celery
carrot onion mixture all these amounts
will be on the site of course we're
going to put a little oil on those just
a touch we're going to put those in a
baking sheet also those are going to go
in the oven at 425 for about 45 minutes
or until browned all right just cook
them till they're brown not very
scientific the beef will be brown the
vegetables will be browned pour off any
excess fat place into a large stockpot
or soup pot I'm going to add five quarts
of water some peppercorns a bay leaf and
a little tomato paste that's it
no salt I'm not going to put herbs I'm
not going to put garlic I'm not going to
put a bunch of stuff I like to flavor
this stuff after I make the stock we're
going to bring that up to a simmer as it
comes to a simmer you're going to skim
off any impurities that foam up to the
top these beef bones are from Steve
normanton as I said they were very clean
very nice alright so I had very little
skimming to do but make sure you skim if
anything bubbles up we're going to bring
that to a simmer gently you do not want
to boil a stock so as soon as it starts
to come up to a simmer and it starts to
boil back it all the way down to low and
that's what you want see that a very
gentle gentle simmer you should have a
few bubbles poking up through the top
here and there but it's not a steady
simmer where the whole thing is kind of
bubbling that has to simmer gently for
eight to twelve hours give it a little
stir once every couple hours and by
simmering very slowly you're going to
get the maximum flavor out of the bone
and you're also going to have a fairly
clear stock you're going to get about a
gallon of stock I started with five
quarts of one quart will evaporate some
people just put a gallon in and they'll
add water once a while either
whay doesn't matter and Here I am 10
hours later done with my beef stock turn
off the heat let it cool to room
temperature take out the big bones so
it's easier to strain strain that
through a fine wire mesh and you're
ready to use by the way I skim most of
the fat off of mine and the rest I'll
pull off here is it cools however if
you're going to store this in the fridge
for a couple days
don't skim the fat leave the fat on top
that'll give it kind of an airtight seal
so then you can pull off the fat when
you're ready to use it and you can keep
this in jars you can put this in the
freezer in bags some people will put
this in ice cube trays and make little
beef stock cubes and then they'll just
throw that in the freezer and use them
as needed this is way cheaper than the
store-bought sure that stuff is
convenient but this tastes incredible
and much cheaper so I hope you make your
own beef stock ask the butcher for some
beef marrow bones and you will be amazed
how easy this is go to the site for all
the ingredients and as always enjoy
